author: {'steamid': '76561199503750226', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 584, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 1, 'playtime_at_review': 340, 'last_played': 1711935619}
review:
Wildfire is a 2D stealth game in a fantasy setting. Reminiscent of Oddworld, you have villagers you can save in most levels. While I like the lighting system in Mark of the Ninja, Wildfire honestly feels like the better stealth game as well as the better representation of what can be done in 2D platforming.

The side-quests ranged from fair to impossible when I began the game. But as I progressed, I unlocked more and more abilities relating to the four elements - you unlock fire, water, earth and air in that order, as well as having spirit abilities from the beginning - that opened up completely new ways to play the game. This made going back to earlier levels to achieve what once felt impossible a lot of fun. So if you're struggling with an optional quest, you can always move along and come back to it later.

Replayability is built into this game through the optional quests, such as ghost, no reloads, speed runs, etc. I can see players finding new and interesting ways to make the game more challenging once mastering the quests. The game is very immersive and it is easy to lose track of time.

The graphics are cute little sprites, reminiscent of 16-bit console games, and despite it not holding your hand like Mark of the Ninja, even though there are only a couple of rudimentary indications as to how well hidden you are and whether or not the enemy can see or hear you, you're never unsure. The controls for keyboard and mouse are nice and simple - like a lot of platform games, the jumping takes a little getting used to, but other than that the controls are fine.

TLDR - Wildfire is very replayable and quite cheap to buy. I would definitely recommend it to anyone who is a fan of stealth games, especially 2D stealth games like Oddworld and Mark of the Ninja, and give it a rating of eight or nine out of ten.
developer_response: That's a very kind review, thank you! We love Oddworld and Mark of the Ninja, and took huge amounts of inspiration from both, so it's gratifying to hear that came through in your experience of playing. Thanks again!

author: {'steamid': '76561197980238525', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 2187, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2187, 'last_played': 1709323322}
review:
This is a very tepid recommendation. It's a very casual puzzle platformer (not an im-sim lmao) that only gets easier the longer you play. It's enjoyable enough. There's nothing particularly wrong with it, though I encountered dozens of bugs in my time with the game.

There are only about 26 stages with one boss stage. In order to unlock all of the powers and upgrades, you need to go into at least NG+, if not NG++. By that point, you can practically finish the levels in your sleep, and you'll get more fun from trolling NPCs than finishing the objectives. I feel like more could've been done with the concepts and mechanics, though. There's still a lot of meat on these bones. Challenge stages would've been nice. A sequel is definitely an option, given the ending of the game. The ability to combine powers seems like an obvious angle that the game doesn't even consider. I'll just say that it's good the game isn't expensive.

Other than those things, there are a bunch of quibbles that they could fix with a polished-up sequel (or a patch to this game): going to NG+ resets all of your settings, some stages have unskippable story segments after them that you have to sit through every time you finish the stage... which you will be doing to collect upgrade points, you sometimes have to fight with the controls to get the game to let you do what you want (not as big of a deal as it sounds)... a variety of other things like that. It's a game that could use more polish.

I have finished this game twice fully and only have the boss stage left on the third run. I mainly replayed to collect achievements and see what a fully-upgraded character plays like. By the end of your first playthrough, you will have seen basically everything this game has to offer. Your replay value will vary. Note that two achievements are locked behind co-op, which I did not touch and will be the only achievements I haven't collected. No idea why game companies continue to lock achievements behind multiplayer, but there it is.

Mildly entertaining toy / 10

author: {'steamid': '76561198016159410', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 119, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 119, 'last_played': 1707777873}
review:
I've really been on the fence about this one: conceptually it's cool, but I honestly find that it's kind of annoying to actually play. I know that I *can* freely reload, but the fact that the game then "punishes" me (in an incredibly minor way, but in a way that's very obvious) makes me feel like I shouldn't do that and should instead restart the whole level, but the levels are actually feel kind of long and it's dull to repeat the early bits to get more attempts on the harder bits. It's not quite "puzzle-y" enough that I feel smart for figuring out "the solution" and the controls aren't tight enough and the enemies are too disruptive to make it a good "skill run through if you get spotted" kind of game. The game functions, the controls work, the art, sound and UI are all perfectly functional and the story and game play are perfectly serviceable: the game is "fine" and I've played much, much worse, but that's not really enough for a recommendation when there are so many options.

I guess the bottom line for me is that I don't really feel enough of a sense of achievement for doing well, but I do feel annoyed for doing badly and so on average I just don't feel like I'm actually having fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198106511544', 'num_games_owned': 1627, 'num_reviews': 182, 'playtime_forever': 1199, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1199, 'last_played': 1705290481}
review:
[b]Sights & Sounds[/b]
- I'll be honest, I love pixel art, but the visuals here are a mixed bag. The backgrounds, for the most part, look gorgeous, as do the sprites for the fire effects. Counter to that are the character designs, which are all tiny and a little ugly. I understand the desire to show more of the level for gameplay purposes, but it does make the characters look a bit featureless and generic
- Additionally, the level design can result in some ugly environments, particularly when you're underground. I just don't like 3/4 of the screen to be covered the cross-section of a wall of stone. If the levels had been more compact and looped around on themselves more, the game would have benefitted in more than one way
- The sountrack is actually pretty good and far better than I initially expected based on the visuals. Nice fantasy orchestral tracks with all the strings and woodwinds you could ask for

[b]Story & Vibes[/b]
- Spoiler-free plot summary: You're just some villager living in a small town and preparing for a harvest festival when a meteor crashes from the sky. Naturally, you decide to go poke it, which gives you magic powers. That would be fantastic news if it weren't for the fact that the local ruler really wanted those powers and decides send her army to tear apart your village and kidnap everyone to figure out who has them. Now you need to stealth your way through the realm to save your friends and get revenge
- All in all, the story is pretty generic, but I think it suffices for a gameplay focused title like Wildfire
- The vibes are hard to articulate, mostly because there are different objectives within each level that you may or may not be trying to achieve. If you're trying to go undetected, the vibes can be tense and calculated. On the other hand, if you're going for a speed run, things can get frantic very quickly

[b]Playability & Replayability[/b]
- After finishing the prologue/tutorial, you're spit out on a Mario-style map of paths and levels. You'll need to stealth or speed run your way through them all, making sure to complete the primary objective
- The core gameplay feels good; the controls all make sense and the jump has a satisfying weight to it. Each level plays out somewhere between a 2D stealth platformer and a puzzle platformer. I know the "immersive sim" tag may get applied here, but I don't think there's enough environmental interaction to qualify (i.e., I can pick up a box and drop it on someone's head, but I can't stack up a pile of them to sneak into a fort)
- Beyond the primary task (ranging from stealing a mission object to saving a predetermined number of kidnapped villagers), each level also has a unique bonus challenge as well as checkmarks for going undetected, not killing anyone, and a speedrun time
- As you progress, you'll obtain the ability to control new elements, which comes in handy as the levels become more complex. Some of these skills can be creatively used in combination as well as with the level's objects and environments for some pretty unique solutions
- This open approach to gameplay really clicked for me when I grabbed a chicken, threw it behind a pair of guards, and lit it with a fireball. The ensuing commotion scared them off a cliff and opened the path forward. Sure, I could have just snuck through the bushes, but that's a much less fun way to approach the puzzles in this game
- I've seen some reviews criticize the difficulty of the game by saying that it's too difficult to complete all of a level's objectives in one run, which in turn necessitates multiple successful completions of each level. That may be true, but I actually appreciated playing each level in different playstyles. I found it kinda fun to do all the "slow" objectives (main, bonus, no kill, and undetected) in my first attempt while keeping an eye out for shortcuts. I'd then use what I'd learned about the level to do the speedrun
- That is to say, this game is largely what you make of it; you can play it however you like, but some ways are more fun than others. I found my own method to be pretty gratifying
- One criticism I would levy has to do with replayability and forcing it on players. I didn't like the fact that there's not enough upgrades to at least unlock every ability. I wouldn't mind not being able to level them all up, but I still feel like I shouldn't have to go through NG+ just to see what all the skills do. Sure, I could replay it to see, but it'll be some time before I return

[b]Overall Impressions & Performance[/b]
- I didn't go into Wildfire with the highest of hopes. Sure, it has a nice Steam rating, but the number of reviews indicates that this title got criminally overlooked. It's such a shame; this is a really fun game with some cool ideas. Sure it isn't perfect, but I still happily got about 20 hours of stealth goodness out of it. Maybe I just have a soft spot for games that let you play them creatively
- Ran perfectly on the Steam Deck

[b]Final Verdict[/b]
- [b]8.5/10[/b]. If you enjoy games like Mark of the Ninja or Gunpoint, you're almost guaranteed to have some fun in Wildfire. It may not be as stylish or complex as those games, but it's still a hidden gem for 2D platform stealth fans

author: {'steamid': '76561199082094351', 'num_games_owned': 81, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 637, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 637, 'last_played': 1704702101}
review:
[h1]+要素齐全的横板潜行游戏，可以简单理解为2D版刺客信条[/h1]
爬墙，躲避，绕路，开锁，分散敌人注意力，惊吓敌人，谋杀敌人等等，要素齐全，麻雀虽小五脏俱全。
[h1]+分量足够的游戏内容量[/h1]
关卡数量和关卡可重复游玩性超出预期，甚至多到有点让人烦躁。
[h1]+个别极具创意，令人印象深刻的有趣关卡[/h1]
是单调的通关流程中为数不多的调味剂。
[h1]+详细明确的引导和教学[/h1]
每次获得新能力游戏都会给一段简单的教学关，游戏新手也能轻松上手。
[h1]+难度和趣味兼具的关卡挑战[/h1]
值得称道的是完成每个关卡的可选目标的过程都是有乐趣的，挑战各不相同，需要用不同的思路去解谜。但是接下来各关相同的通用挑战：不被发现——这个还好，毕竟是一款潜行游戏，不被发现才符合标准的游戏体验——，不杀人，不存档，速通。完成起来简直折磨。到游戏中后期我选择与自己和解，不在追求完美通关。
[h1]+多样的通关方式[/h1]
三种不同的的法术和数量繁多的陨石碎片——附加不同的能力，可以类比为遗物，但是最多只能携带三个——给同一关卡带来了多样的通关方式。
[h1]+令人耳目一新的最终章[/h1]
涉嫌剧透，谨慎观看。[spoiler]最终章一改前面关卡潜行的通关风格，改为巫师之间的法术对决，虽然做的很烂，但倒是使游戏体验发生了很大变化。[/spoiler]
[h1]*标准的剧情展开与发展，颇有深意的结尾[/h1]
主角因缘际会获得力量，拯救村民，报仇雪恨的王道剧情。虽然俗套，但情绪渲染到位的话，依然称得上是个好故事，并不会招人厌恶。
[h1]*BGM质量平平[/h1]
只有个别两首音乐不错，其他也就听个响的程度吧。
[h1]-中后期敌人种类太少，关卡变化不足[/h1]
仔细数来游戏竟然只有三种敌人。虽然每关的地图都不尽相同，但总是重复应对同一种敌人，加之2D关卡变化又少，导致在游戏中后期明显失去了乐趣，游玩动力不足。
[h1]总体推荐[/h1]

author: {'steamid': '76561198068982092', 'num_games_owned': 909, 'num_reviews': 401, 'playtime_forever': 179, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 179, 'last_played': 1703356340}
review:
While the game feels a bit clunky at first, it really comes together as you get used to the gameplay and unlock new powers. And the powers are very well realised which makes the gameplay quite dynamic and it's very satisfying to execute your plan. The levels are also pretty well realised puzzle grounds to find your own solution to the exit with a bunch of extra side-challenges to accomplish if you feel like it.

Overall around 7/10, the perfectly executed gimmick is the most fun part of the game.

review:
[h1] 这是一款潜行解谜游戏，非战斗风格[/h1] 
游戏为像素画风，画面精美，色彩丰富，该有的细节全都有，主角操控的三种元素力量，看似单一，但把技能等级升上去后，不同元素就能组合出不同的衍生技，看得出来制作组在游戏性上下了很大功夫，同样，关卡设计也十分用心，逻辑性很强，加上主角的各种技能，过关方式并不唯一，可重复游玩性极高。
中文翻译也做到了信达雅，非常诙谐幽默。
唯一一个不像缺点的缺点，就是完美通关条件太苛刻了，真的苦逼了手残党和成就党（笑哭）

author: {'steamid': '76561197980503707', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 92, 'playtime_forever': 1024, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 512, 'last_played': 1692967136}
review:
If you plan on getting this game, keep in mind 3 things.

1) Don't bother with completionist thoughts and ignore objectives you don't want to do, leave that for NewGame+ or stretch out a few to increase some of your ability points enough to get something "in reach".
2) There is a lot of jank with input (at least I feel, in keyboard + mouse). Also I've not been able to use a controller as a second player properly, not sure what went wrong but player 2 kept trying to target what player 1 with kbm was targetting.
3) This game was fun enough, but it feels like it tries to push speedrunning a bit too much and those speed goals are quite tight in too many levels for a "casual" gamer.

If you keep those things in mind, Wildfire is a good enough game. You'll be wishing a few things were different, including how many meteor shards you can have equipped, but it stands as a mediocre stealth platformer with a VERY AWKWARD NAME to google if you need some extra help.

Also, I have no idea why they made it so janky-awkward to free prisoners from their bonds; it could seriously have had some kind of hold-button prompt to do it if the issue was how fast pressing a button was, but the in-game way of "breaking" the bonds is just awful when you don't have fire at hand or sparingly enough in the levels you need to use it as such.

review:
Great game, really love the physics it reproduces in 2D, the puzzles are interesting, the mechanics are also great and the upgrades make it so that if you had a problem beating a particular challenge in a previous level you can go back and beat it with more leeway.

The story is pretty simple but the gameplay mechanics are very entertaining. That said, some of the meteor shard upgrades can make finishing certain levels a LOT easier. "Heavy Feet" (which allows you to knockout enemies by falling on top of them) and "One Free Fright" (which makes the first enemy that detects you to panic, which can save you from a fatal mistake) seem pretty much a must, so like people said, if you struggle completing some of the challenges, maybe try going back once you have reached the final level or until you start the new game + campaign.

Its a great stealth game in 2D and the magic mechanics are very fun to use.

author: {'steamid': '76561198061165996', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 859, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 859, 'last_played': 1689278657}
review:
It's actually a nice little game but it lacks polish. If the devs were to release a follow-up where they iron out some of the weaker aspects of the game, I'm sure it would turn out great. Those being:

- The music is rather generic
- There is little enemy variety
- Gameplay, while fun most of the time, gets repetitive
- There is only little entertainment in replaying levels. It feels more like a chore
- Little to no story. The ending felt unrewarding

I'd love to see more variety when it comes to level design:
- Add additional mission types, for instance, following a particular character without getting noticed
- Add endbosses that you can tackle in different ways (sneaking vs open confrontation)
- Increase replay value by switching things up. Add more modi. Let it rain acid, make the floor lava or lower gravity

I hope this is seen as constructive criticism by the devs. For the most part, I really enjoyed the game and can recommend it if you don't mind some of the above mentioned flaws.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046424855', 'num_games_owned': 253, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 1176, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1176, 'last_played': 1689007810}
review:
I've seen this game being compared to Gunpoint and Mark of The Ninja, but I didn't played either of them, so for me it resembles Thief, but in 2d (and instead of being trained by Keepers we're now full fledged Pagan), also that old 2d Prince of Persia game with rotoscoped movements. This game has many systems underneath, like weight and impulse of objects, sounds, gorgeous fire that can spread and fill areas with smoke, cinders and upward air currents. There is also water and tree magic, which kinda makes main protagonist more like avatar instead of sneaky arsonist. The artstyle, music and plot reminds me of the animated movies like Secret of Kells and Wolfwalkers (and obvious Avatar The Last Airbender/Legend of Korra). 

There are many approaches to objectives and missions in this game, however you won't be able to use them all when you encounter them first time because you cannot acquire all skills in one playthrough, so many objectives can be achieved only with powerful late skills from water/earth/spirit magic. So you got to to complete game two times to get all skills and perks from meteorite shards. And one playthrough is about 12-18 hours. And your first playthrough will be rather messy, because you won't have much skills besides fire arsonist and low/weak water and earth skills, and you'll need some luck to acquire some useful perks from shards, because they are randomised and you need to replay level from full restart to get some actually useful roll on shard pickup (kinda like Dishonored if you know what I mean). So don't expect to get ghost+no kill+ no reload and other awards from the first try on first playthrough on most levels.

review:
If you are going to use a controller, beware.
Randomly swaps between controller input sources.

I'm using a virtualized Xbox layout on top of an old controller I own, it swaps between the native input source and the virtual source at random but more often after tutorial messages or enemy conversation.
For something that requires a certain degree of tightness, having my jump button swap from A to X and back at random makes this game unplayable using a controller.
developer_response: Hey there, you can actually solve this problem by going to Steam > Settings > Enable Steam Input [...] and adjusting the setting per controller, either enabled or disabled, to fix this issue.

author: {'steamid': '76561197967449126', 'num_games_owned': 2389, 'num_reviews': 367, 'playtime_forever': 343, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 343, 'last_played': 1686503840}
review:
Wildfire is a stealth 2D platformer where you have magical powers and can control the elements to get around guards or solve puzzles. The game play was quite enjoyable but seeing trailers, it looked more like an immersive sim while the game didn't feel like one, it felt very on rails. The game was still fun but it left me wanting more hoping for more freedom and options within each stage. The later city stages had some more freedom which made those levels particularly fun but it was only a couple of stages. 

It is still a fun indie title. I was hoping for a bit more so it left me a little disappointed but I still think it's worth your time. I would definitely look forward to a sequel with larger stages that gave you more options to solve each situation.

review:
It's not bad, but it becomes a drag during the middle, and doesn't reach its full potential.
You'll want to go in and just light levels on fire and float around in bubbles, but really you'll spend most of your time hiding in a corner waiting for a guard patrol to walk past. Because it's hook is the elemental abilities the stealth on its own isn't fully featured enough to be particularly fun. And it takes ages to unlock said elemental abilities - you wont get at least a couple of the really game-changing ones before new game+.
The game starts to shine when you've unlocked a bunch of abilities and you're going back for challenges and unlocks, but the payoff isn't worth the slog. A excellent setup for a sequel where the devs cut straight to the fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198171251563', 'num_games_owned': 407, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 924, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 924, 'last_played': 1679616614}
review: This game looks fantastic, and really scratches that mark of the ninja itch nothing else really was able to in a couple of years. If you like this sort of game, its definitely a good grab just for that.However.... There are a couple of things, making me not go back and play it 5 times (or try ng+) like mark of the ninja did. [hr][/hr]First of all, the most annoying thing: The autosave/checkpoints.The levels are not segments (most of the time) and instead an area you can travel around freely. While technically a great thing, this means there is checkpoints you can activate yourself.... By walking over them. Not by a button press, not by selecting a save slot next to them, no, they save EVERY TIME you walk over them, meaning in a hectic situation, or just by complete accident you can save over your game in a bad spot and since loading from a checkpoint deletes your auto save for some reason, its super easy to brick your progress for a level and have to restart. The levels are quite short and nothing is very hard to overcome so it isnt a huge issue, but nevertheless its just annoying. This could easily be solved by more auto save slots or making the checkpoints activate on interaction by button. [hr][/hr]Then, the AI of the people you have to rescue in some levels. They cant: Climb ladders/vines; Jump down a ledge unless there is padded floor below (and sometimes not even then, which is extra annoying if you went out of your way to pad the floor); Follow you after being carried, which would be ok if the way to make them follow you wasnt a whistle that attracts enemies. All of this does not make the game harder, it only leads to carrying your allies one by one along the exact same easy path that they refuse to walk themselves. Sometimes for up to 6 people. Again, this is only bearable because the levels are short and easy.[hr][/hr]And lastly, there is one item that just trivializes the game entirely. You can find a shard that lets you knock out almost every enemy, for free, with no drawbacks, just by falling from 1x your characters height on their head and carrying them away. This feels very strong in comparison to the actual fancy magic abilities you get, which mostly stun or distract enemies, and kinda made using them for anything else than to get above enemies obsolete.[hr][/hr]Regardless, the concept is really fun, and i recommend playing it at least once, despite needing some polishing around the edges.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037224853', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 356, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 356, 'last_played': 1679163412}
review:
An amazing game, truly deserving of the title of immersive sim. You can play this game however you want; you can choose one element and stick with it the whole game, making the gameplay feel like a one-trick pony in a good way, or you can be versatile and swap between earth, fire and water/ice (elements) and bring about a chaotic hodgepodge of the three. The potential to create chaos in this game should not be overlooked- that's where most of the fun lies, IMO. I'd often alternate between elements and try to come up with the most emergent scenarios possible, and it'd work most of the time. Enemies can destroy shackles tied to prisoners' arms. Enemies can be trapped in water bubbles. Ice cubes can be used for platforming. Vines can be rearranged into parachutes. This is one game where what you see falls short of what you can get out of it, so long as you're creative.
My only gripe is that final boss. Games don't need bosses, especially immersive sims. Here's a heads-up to the devs: instead of feeling forced to squeeze in boss fights, which unfortunately many devs still find necessary in order to be able to call their games "full-fledged games" (whatever the hell that's supposed to mean..), why not just make the final level bigger and more challenging? Why not make the game more memorable that way, instead of a silly final boss battle? The final (and only) boss of Wildfire is not nearly as frustrating and out-of-place as the one in A Plague Tale, but still. It wasn't needed. But overall, a great experience. 8.5/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000024248', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 1505, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1505, 'last_played': 1679202728}
review:
Wildfire is a great indie game that merges stealth, elemental powers, and a pretty good story. Levels were different enough to not be repetitive, and there are multiple strategies to complete them. As you progress through the story, the upgrades you unlock make going back to earlier levels to complete the bonus challenges easier - which lead to more upgrades. Speaking of, the challenges were challenging, but only until you figure them out. Fully upgrading certain powers makes the challenges incredibly easy. I really enjoy the fact that you don't have to complete all of the bonus challenges in one try.
If I were to add a negative to this review, I was not a big fan of having to loop through the game to NG+2 in order to fully upgrade all of the abilities. But that is a minor negative.

Overall, Wildfire is quite fun, polished, and worth a try. I am glad to have my name in the Kickstarter backers portion of the credits.

author: {'steamid': '76561198145711263', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 62, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 48, 'last_played': 1676825670}
review:
Though the graphics are nice enough and what I've been able to see of the magic system looks like it would be fun, this game is obnoxious to play. The controls feel like your character is sliding on ice all of the time, and you use the same button both to slide and to hide from enemies meaning that you will extremely often leap right into the arms of a guard you're trying to avoid instead of taking cover. The collectible systems are fun, but I don't like that they are randomised; the optional upgrades to find give you a random upgrade that can be completely useless when you recieve it because it's for an ability you don't have yet and kickstarter collectibles are on random enemies so if you want them all you either have to hunt down the guard with each one in a level on its own run or just get lucky. 

Don't bother with the challenges. If you're the kind of person that likes to start games with ghost/non-lethal runs of stealth games then you won't have fun here because the game seems to be designed so that those options are only viable with late-game upgrades to pad out the runtime (and again, floaty controls make trying to do so extremely painful). It's strange, too - you can overhear humanising dialogue between enemies and your character's demeanour make it seem like playing non-lethally is the right way to go but you just have to immolate some people to get past even the second stage.


Overall I wouldn't recommend this game, but I want to give it another try where I play as a heartless bastard and forget about the down button entirely - maybe the game will be better like that... the music is quite pleasant too, which is always an upside, but it's a shame that the actual game is the weakest part of the whole thing
developer_response: You are not required to press the down button to hide in grass; simply let go of the sprint button and you will hide automatically.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970572861', 'num_games_owned': 1528, 'num_reviews': 113, 'playtime_forever': 591, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 591, 'last_played': 1676494105}
review:
This is a cool game.
I like systems-driven magic gameplay, and have yet to play a platformer that I feel really took advantage of it. So Wildfire is unique to my experience in that regard. Definitely worth a play.

The game plays a little like a mix between Vagante and Abe's Oddysee, where staying in control of your approach (AKA stealth and planning) are central to pulling off successful maneuvers. Your character is very mobile, much moreso when you unlock more elemental abilities, but also things can go south real quick when they don't go as planned.
Unlike either Vagante or Abe's Oddysee, the game has an overworld which allows you to freely select and replay missions, which is essential since each mission has a list of challenges which provide more skill points when you complete them. As a result, you may end up replaying missions over and over, mastering them fully to farm as many skill points as you can.
This may sound tedious to some, and it is optional, but being that the game is systems-driven, it means that the mission has the potential to play out differently each time. So I found it really fun to replay the levels.

At the end of the day I think Wildfire accomplished well what it set out to do.
I was a little disappointed that I didn't unlock all the game's abilities in my first run considering I 100%'d every level, but this also incentivizes the game's NG+ mode, so I think it was a smart strategy. Also the game's achievements are well designed IMO. I expect I will spend some time in NG+ and that's not something I normally do.

I have a few very minor complaints.
[list][*]I think Wildfire is the wrong title for this game
[*]It's nice that the camera zooms and pans but I hate how the pixels get distorted when you do that; I'd prefer a fixed resolution -- the game has a lot of options but this is not one of them
[*]Some of the levels feel large and empty; unpolished
[*]A lot of the writing just isn't great IMO -- doesn't fit well into the gameplay and comes across as amateurish and out-of-place, especially the poetry[/list]

Apologies to the writer; The base story is good; fine motivators for the quest, mostly believable villainy. But I think the lore is bad, and I barely skimmed most of the level intro blurbs. I'm in favor of lore being in a game, but good lore feels more connected to the gameplay and the story currently being told. Most of the poems especially are just a random short story loosely related to a power you just unlocked, or tell some parable about a random character that has nothing to do with the the game's plot. It feels like it's wasting my time. The best writing was one that was part of an optional level objective, since it married environmental storytelling, level design, and lore. The rest bogs down the game IMO. Less is more, especially for action games. One punchy sentence would be better than a four stanza poem (unless that poem is profound, which these were not). I hope this is useful critique.

review:
Una autentica joya plataformera que me paso desapercibida. Compre la clave en una tienda por menos de 2€ y no puedo estar mas satisfecho. El juego me hace sentir que vuelvo a la época de los 16bits con su aspecto retro , pixelado pero con unos gráficos supercuidados , las animaciones están muy bien hechas y son simpáticas. (Me recuerda mucho a un juego de Amiga que se llama Benefactor !!) Pero lo verdaderamente genial de este juego es la jugabilidad. Manejas un jovenzuelo que se convierte en hechicero sin querer y puede manejar los elementos. Los malos de turno quieren robar sus poderes y el quiere rescatar a los aldeanos que han sido capturados y esa es la trama , avanzar por los niveles intentando completar los objetivos de cada uno. (que pueden ser desde liberar a un aldeano hasta robar unas llaves yendo disfrazado de soldado enemigo por ejemplo)... Usas la fuerza de la tierra para crear lianas por las que subir a plataformas elevadas o enraizar a los enemigos, el fuego para quemar la madera que retiene a los prisioneros , el agua para crear pompas que te permiten volar .. o simplemente apagar un incendio que has provocado ! todo esto entre otras muchas mas aplicaciones de los elementos que hacen que sea muy divertido. La dificultad , creo que es bastante baja , no hubo ni un nivel que me hiciera sudar. Al acabar el juego hay un "Nueva Partida +" que definitivamente probaré. También dispone del modo "Speed Run" tan popular en los juegos de plataformas.

En resumen , si estas aburrido y quieres jugar algo para pasar el rato , por el precio que tiene , yo no lo dudaria ni un segundo.

author: {'steamid': '76561198068521118', 'num_games_owned': 902, 'num_reviews': 101, 'playtime_forever': 654, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 654, 'last_played': 1672484917}
review:
A very pleasant combination of a classic 2D platformer with stealth mechanics, paying homage to other similar games. The elemental mechanics are fun, but they need some time to get used to. It gets better when unlocking new skills, allowing to beat the levels in less obvious and more exciting ways. I wish the protagonist would be more aggressive and deal damage directly to enemies, allowing for a perfect blend of stealth and combat, but I understand it’s by design. The graphics style is cute and the atmosphere is gorgeous.

Now, completing all the levels with doing as much of the additional goals as possible in one go may be frustrating, that’s why I recommend only focusing on main tasks and returning for additional stuff later.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034183075', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 655, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 655, 'last_played': 1672450317}
review: Why do we have to do so much with one button? Want to throw an element instead of read a sign or open a tomb? Sorry. Explain the logic of bobcats being afraid of fire as long as you aren't close. Terror increases with proximity. Good basic idea, and I wanted to like, but I can't stand games that handicap players in the name of replay-ability. Want me to need to return to an area? Take a look at a Zelda game or one of its clones. That's how you do it but not by power starving. Give me a power or don't. Don't make me level it up until its finally useful. That's not challenge; that's annoyance. Few games manage to be both sandbox and puzzle. This isn't it. It forces solutions until you have powered up enough to finally enjoy some freedom in play. Can't give it a meh so I gotta give it a nah. No motivation to finish.

author: {'steamid': '76561197987708808', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 121, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 115, 'last_played': 1672921384}
review:
Over 90% of the positive reviews have a total playtime under 2 hours, because this game very quickly becomes extremely tedious. 

So many escort missions with braindead AI that doesn't follow you or just jumps onto spikes forcing you to restart. 
Aiming is pixel perfect and unreliable.
Enemy AI is buggy and inconsistent, sometimes getting stuck pacing 2ft back and forth forcing you to restart to fix it.
Weird lag on jumping, combined with a very awkward feeling where everyone in this game seems to take 3 quick steps followed by 3 slow steps making movement feel sluggish and awful.
Story and gameplay clash: you gain your fire powers after being set on fire, yet throughout the rest of the game fire will kill you. 

You can get the same experience for free from browser games.

review:
The game does a lot of interesting things — the spell mechanics and versatility, focusing on stealth over violence and providing avenues to embrace either — and encourages you to replay earlier levels after building your character.

However, these benefits plus the detriments — unskippable in-the-mission cutscenes, enemies stunlocking you, certain very difficult missions — weren't enough to keep me hooked after completing it once. The New Game+ feature is meant for someone other than me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022980827', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 245, 'playtime_forever': 677, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 677, 'last_played': 1671854055}
review:
Wildfire is a pixel art 2D stealth platformer, where you have to use your elemental abilities to free your fellow villagers and escape the numerous hunting parties that are after you, as well as avoiding environmental hazards. There’s a good amount of puzzle solving (especially if you aren’t doing the bare minimum in stages), and replayabilitiy if you want to complete all the optional extras for different awards (no kills, unseen, speedrun ect), an expanded new game+ mode, and couch co-op for some extra mayhem. Also you can set most things on fire, like nearly everything. I’d highly recommended picking it up, though if you only plan on doing a minimal run then play time will likely be around 6 hours depending on skill level.

[b]Story[/b]
The game does a great job of drip feeding you the story, keeping you exploring the stages and notes to slowly expand on why events are happening. You play as an unknown villager, one who might be marked as a village protector. As a part of your trial, you come across a strange, glowing meteorite, which grants you the power to control fire. As you rush back to your village, you see it burning, with soldiers marching off survivors, and yourself being hunted for being a witch.  You follow the raiding force, trying to free your fellow villages, and figure out why this is happening while harnessing your new powers.

[b]Gameplay[/b]
I thoughts the gameplay was fairly slick and well designed. You have a good range of normal movements (walking, jumping, swimming, climbing & sliding) with faster versions (like running) creating noise (in a bubble around you) that enemies can use to detect you.  You are mostly defenceless, with few options at your disposal to directly confront enemies, with most of your options being limited to distracting enemies, or stunning them, though as you unlock upgrades or pick up equipable skills the options expand.

There’s around 25 stages, with them being split into different environments (forest, caves, mountains and city), each which presents different environmental hazards. The beginning areas are lush with grass to hide in, but these also make excellent areas to set enemies on fire if needed to make them panic. The downside being that burnt grass generates noise as you move through it, and no longer hides you. The icy environment makes control of the character more difficult as you slide, and noise might cause icicles to drop on you. Some areas can freeze your character to death if they don’t keep close to a heat source. The caves are full of bobcats, which can smell you if you are within their range and will actively hunt you if you are detected. The cities act as a mix of everything, while introducing enemies that are immune to fire.

The upgrade system is well thought out, and lets you pick from what you think will help you the most (from what’s unlocked). While the major element class (fire, earth and water) is locked behind story progression, it does give you the ability to become well versed in using them. Every new power unlocked has its own tutorial, which you have to do to continue. These upgrades greatly expand on the move set available to you, and can significantly help you move through areas. You can’t get everything unlocked in one play through, that’s what’s the NG+ mode is for, as well as expanding on the guard’s search patterns. Each stage has multiple collectables, from elemental upgrades (which you can pick from depending on the offering you make), random meteorite shards to collect (which buff different abilities), as well as other collectables (for achievements). Each stage has optional extras you can do, which grant additional upgrade points (for buffing health, ability range ect). I’d say most of these are meant for NG+, as you have a full moveset at your disposal to use.

While the map screen shows you what objectives have been completed for each stage, it would have been great to show some of the other collectables as well, though they do carry across playthroughs. I didn’t find the game buggy, and encountered no issues though it does have a long initial load time, though I was playing with a controller which might be the preferred way to play.

[b]Graphics[/b]
The graphics are designed in that retro pixel art, but actually look quite good. There’s no mistaking what things are, your powers advise what can interact with what objects (hover your fireball over a plant and you will see it show it will go up in flames). There is a good amount of trial and error involved, and you set a new checkpoint everytime you touch a shrine. While each stage only has 1 exit, there usually multiple paths through or ways to tackle each given situation, though some of these will be highly dependent on what upgrades you have.

[b]Music[/b]
The sound effects in the game were good. Moving on different surfaces produces different noises, and running increases the tempo. The game lacks any direct voice work, though all the guards scream when they panic, and make other noises as they move through different levels of alertness. Interacting with the elements or objects in different ways all have their own effects, some which are critical to traversing stages. The music is actually quite good and really suits the game, though seems to fade quickly from memory when not being actively listened to.

[b]DLC[/b]
The only DLC available is the soundtrack, which I thought was quite good. Not sure if I’d listen to it outside the game though

[b]Achievements[/b]
If your aiming for 100% achievements then I think its possible, but you need to be prepared to sink some time into playing the game. You need to do at least 2 runs (NG+), complete all the optional objectives, and play in co-op mode

For more reviews please visit https://store.steampowered.com/curator/31327216/

author: {'steamid': '76561198114597383', 'num_games_owned': 170, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 2122, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2122, 'last_played': 1666848451}
review:
[h1][u]POSITIVE:[/u][/h1]
Wildfire is a nice, fun stealthy magic game, gladly warming the hearts of those who love the pixel art style in video games. It offers fun mechanics through the world progression and the game can be beaten first time in a few hours, possibly a day or two. Few glitches and such may arise, which honestly can make the game funny with how stuff happens. The poems were [b][u][i]BEAUTIFUL[/i][/u][/b]. Alongside the art, the poems are beautiful and offer a different lore to the game as well. I find the music was okay.
[hr][/hr]
[h1][u]NEGATIVE[/u][/h1]
However, we now tackle the annoying tidbits. After completing the game, you get the option for a New Game +, which allows you to maintain your powers and progression system from the previous run, perfect for those who, even after 100% completing their run, realize that there are still gaps in the magic system. This is fun, however, as you can now tackle the levels in a new, more powerful way. However, a second run is still not enough to finish the magic system, and one needs to go into a new New Game +, which seems...annoying somewhat. And something I experienced was how I started the second New Game + and quit the game for the day during the opening cut-scenes, only to come back the next day and finding out that doing so eliminates the previous runs and progression one has done, so it must be done from the beginning. Extremely annoying which I find can probably be fixed with an update.
[hr][/hr]
[h1][u]OVERALL:[/u][/h1]
Overall, I liked the game. Good story, fun take on magic used for stealth more than attacking. Beautiful pixel art, beautiful poems, and a nice story. If acquiring this game, make sure you enjoy it with a buddy as well, but be careful when aiming to complete the achievements.
[h1] 7/10 [/h1]

author: {'steamid': '76561197999102547', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 338, 'playtime_forever': 31, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 31, 'last_played': 1663645676}
review:
Very good little stealth game. Great physics. Absolutely worth your time and money, especially if you enjoy stealthy platforming and playing with fire.

Now, let's talk about that quote--

“[Recalls] some of the best aspects of genre titans like Assassin’s Creed and Hitman with the immersive elemental effects of Dishonored.”

Today I learned: 
1. The best aspect of Assassin's Creed is hiding in tall grass. 
2. The best aspect of Hitman is the simplistic enemy A.I. it lifted from Metal Gear Solid.
3. Dishonored is immersive because it has elemental effects.
4. Dishonored has elemental effects?   

To be clear, I don't fault Sneaky Bastards or Humble Games for using the quote, but, like, Gunpoint had been out for 7 years before Wildfire was released. 

If you're gonna compare a side-scrolling pixel art stealth game to other games, maybe choose another side-scrolling pixel art stealth game?

author: {'steamid': '76561199093890913', 'num_games_owned': 452, 'num_reviews': 92, 'playtime_forever': 485, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 485, 'last_played': 1663561438}

author: {'steamid': '76561197970351460', 'num_games_owned': 1392, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 1263, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1263, 'last_played': 1663036176}
review:
A solid platformer. Just enough narrative to keep it interesting. I like the approach used to reach level goals. You can do several run-throughs, each focused on different goals, or for extra challenge try to get several in a single run-through. For example, a no-reload, undetected, no kills run-through.  Then later a speed-run. Then later the secondary/extended objectives. Usually I don't like replaying levels but this game hit me right and I played through each level several times.

I had issues with the xbox controller timing out and reconnecting in this game that I haven't seen in other games but it could be unrelated.

Edit: The controller issues were unrelated to this game. Started playing a different game this week and am experienced the same controller issues. :(

author: {'steamid': '76561198048646254', 'num_games_owned': 646, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 532, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 21, 'last_played': 1699708820}
review:
Hogyan lehet egy csirkével vitorlázni? Miként lehet a tüzet meglovagolni, és indával fogságba ejteni az ellenséget? Hogyan lehet a hiúzok között észrevétlenül átjutni?

Minderre és még rengeteg további kreatív felhasználási módra derül fény ebben az igen kedves pixelart játékban, mialatt az elhurcolt falubéliek megmentésén fáradozol. A terepviszonyok és lehetőségek szerint lopakodva, álcázva, elrejtőzve, vagy mindent lángba borítva tudsz előre jutni, miközben az ellenség egyre komolyabb erővel és felkészüléssel próbál megállítani.

Lehetőség van co-op módra is, ahol egymást segítve könnyebben juthattok előre.

A játék hamarosan magyar nyelven is elérhetővé válik a magyaritasok.hu oldalon.

author: {'steamid': '76561197961171525', 'num_games_owned': 268, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 185, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 185, 'last_played': 1662569332}
review:
The concept of Wildfire is fine, but a few gameplay elements quickly soured the experience.

[u]Speedrun, but not speedrun friendly[/u]
[list][*]No auto skip for cutscenes/dialog every time you restart.
[*]No auto skip for cutscenes at level complete you've already scene.
[*]Having to manually exit tutorial/side story levels after level complete.
[/list]

[u]Escorts[/u]
Saving the villagers quickly becomes a focal point of the game. Stealth games are already slow, but then you add multiple NPCs you have wait for and manually yeet around ground patrols and it becomes pure tedium. The very first mission with multiple people to rescue moves at a snails pace as you wait for patrols to pass so you can drag your slow tail behind you. It's even worse in the sections where you have to throw people. One mistake means they get hacked to pieces and you can't do anything but reset.

[u]RNG upgrades[/u]
The passive upgrades found in levels are random. Some of them are really strong, while others range from pointless to behaving more like a Halo skull (making the game harder). Anything would have been better over replaying a level over and over to try and get one you want.

[u]Bloated RPG element[/u]
The upgrade system adds so little, but feels invasive. Every time you have a point to spent it reminds you when you try to start a level. You're also blocked from unlocking useful upgrades until you've put multiple points into upgrades before it. The upgrades were so minor they didn't feel like they did anything meaningful. Huzzah! Range went up 0.13m. Knowing the game had to be designed to be completed with players getting the minimal (if any) upgrades makes it feel even more pointless.

[u]Conclusion[/u]
The good ideas weren't interesting or fun enough in the first 3 hours to make me want to press through a tedious, repetitive, and dull experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198093121331', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1750, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 379, 'last_played': 1661969552}
review:
Une très agréable surprise. Wildfire vous met rapidement dans l'ambiance : de l'infiltration qui ressemble davantage à un puzzle-game, où il vous faudra réfléchir aux différentes possibilités qui s'offrent à vous par rapport à vos capacités et au level-design extrêmement bien pensé. Il m'a tout de suite fait ressentir les mêmes sensations que Mark of the Ninja à l'époque.

Vous voulez passer sans vous faire repérer ? Créez des diversions, faites quelques détours et prenez des raccourcis en utilisant vos compétences à bon escient.
Vous voulez vous faire plaisir et tuer un maximum de gardes (après tout, pourquoi pas) ? Effrayez-les pour les faire tomber d'assez haut, piégez-les intelligemment avec un incendie,... les possibilités sont assez nombreuses pour assurer une excellente rejouabilité.

Revenir dans un niveau précédent avec de nouveaux éléments maîtrisés et de nouvelles capacités changera votre façon d'aborder les choses. Sans parler des défis disponibles dans chaque zone qui demanderont pas mal de temps et d'investissement pour espérer atteindre le 100%. Je devrais bientôt terminer le jeu une première fois et j'ai hâte de découvrir le New Game +, je suis parti pour quelques très belles heures supplémentaires.

review:
[quote]想象一下在你身上能看到我们的身影，
你那热切的双手也能将火焰唤醒。
噢，当那闪亮的火花在夜空中闪耀，
引得孩童追逐，长者眉开眼笑。
多年的宿怨消散于无形，
你丢下武器，享受片刻安宁。

或许会有一个小毛孩想亲身感受，
他笨拙地投出一簇火焰去温暖他的脚趾头。
“妈妈，我不小心烫坏了脚，快来帮忙！”
难以置信人们会将经历过的一切掩藏，
他们的痛苦、他们的错误还有曾经的惊天秘密。
“噢，亲爱的宝贝，我会很快帮你弄好，快来这里。”

有些人或许永远不会迈出第一步，
去踏上挖掘自身潜能的旅途。
但不管怎样，当你遇到巫师就会知道，
他那美丽的光环正是你自己的写照。[/quote]

author: {'steamid': '76561197989057028', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 1158, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1158, 'last_played': 1657345780}
review:
Fantastic little game. One of the most innovative stealth games I've played in years. It has elements of immersive sims brought into a neat side scrolling platformer. There are many magical abilities and you won't be able to upgrade them all fully on your first playthrough. Like Deus Ex, you can build your character to take a number of different approaches. The interactivity of the environments and the "chemistry" engine of heat and cold also leads to a lot of fun immersive sim interactions.

I played the game and then immediately beat it again with New Game+ and upgraded all the way the second time. It was great fun both times and now I want to play it a third time with a friend in co-op. I'm excited to see what's next for this studio.

review:
This is a perfectly acceptable couch co-op experience.

Platforming is good.
Abilities are interesting and varied. I get the sense that you can go very different paths and solve puzzles in ab very different manner depending on your playstyle.
Good music, sound effects were noticeably great.


All around it's a solid game, though nothing to write home about. Personally, I don't believe I would have played it through single player. However it was and enjoyable 8 hours spent in co-op.
4/7

review:
There are a bunch of issues i have with this game. There are multiple bugs and reloading does not feel streamlined considering how often you will do it when completing level challenges. Progression feels a littleall over the place. You can softlock yourself with dumb elemental upgrade choices, meteor fragments found are completely random. Difficulty curve is also wonky when you try to go for high amount of additional level objectives

And i enjoy it despite those flaws. Pixel art is good, the amount of options in clearing the levels is enjoyable without undermining the difficulty of said challenges. Local multiplayer option is great, and core game mechanics are deterministic

author: {'steamid': '76561198315179091', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 309, 'playtime_forever': 543, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 215, 'last_played': 1653317582}
review:
Nice stealth/puzzles game.

I love the pixel art personally here. Very pleasant.
Playability is also good. Controls are responsive. Controller is well supported.
Music is nice. Soldier shouts are boring but that is ok, it is not all the time.
There are humor touches that are really good.

What seems to annoy some players from bad reviews is, it is slow paced. Yep, that is a stealth game.
All challenges cannot be achieved at the same time on the same map. Yep again, maps are short and intended to be replayed in a different style to get all the achievements.
But also nothing force you to play all the challenges. You can just play it the way you want. If you think speedruns are not for you then just play it slow paced by completing or trying to the other challenges. They are many per maps.
For what I see and believe, succeeding challenges permit to earn points that you may attribute to your skill tree especially to help succeeding other challenges. Finishing basically a map provides enough points to continue the journey,
Anyway, I have personally no problem with this. I already have done all the challenges for the first set of maps. Like said, maps are short so, it is fun.

If you wants all the achievement, there is a major issue. At least 2 of them requires to play the game in co-op mode.

Definitely a go for me.

review:
The game has some interesting mechanics, and it's basically a puzzle/stealth game with specific goals for each level. More of a thinker/problem-solving game than anything else. Which isn't really what I was expecting. So the game's fun, but it got boring for me, because I wanted it to be something else.

Still giving it a thumbs up though, because when you're in the mood for that sort of thing, this game can be fun. I don't know how much content there is, but the map seems pretty big so I can fathom it's worth the price point.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006575550', 'num_games_owned': 1631, 'num_reviews': 625, 'playtime_forever': 459, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 459, 'last_played': 1648432575}
review:
Wildfire is quite enjoyable! And before you consider buying the game you must understand it's a puzzle game. It's not if you can complete the levels because they're kinda easy. But completing them the way you want can be challenging. I enjoyed the stealth mechanic and figuring out the best way through. I'm a fan of stealth games and Mark of the Ninja is one of my favorite games.

So the magic in Wildfire is the star of the show. It's fun to throw elements at enemies to see what happens. They're not the brightest crayon in the box. The mechanics are interesting and unlike anything I've played before. And it opens up a lot of options for completing a level. You can choose to use the elements to burn down everything or scare the enemies. There's a lot of opportunity to freestyle your way to the end. It works very well.

The stealth works well enough but I could have used a little more health. Wildfire shows sound bubbles and the guard's alert statuses. But you will have to learn some of those sounds, like dropping from a far distance. I understand it's a challenge to show the player the information but it led to many mistakes. Also, the enemy's line of sight isn't obvious. Some enemies could see me through a crack and others were somewhat blind. That kind of inconsistency is annoying but didn't completely ruin the experience.

Anyway, if you're anything like me you'll want to replay levels. The first time through to complete it and then a few more times to get all the optional objectives. I think the game is a little pushy about these alternative goals. So much so it seems like they're required. YOU DON'T HAVE TO DO THIS. I really wanted to replay levels because the side quests are interesting. Burning 90% of the vegetation or completing a level without getting wet is what I came for. If you're the type of person that must 100% something before moving on this could be a problem. Some of the objectives can take a long time with a lot of waiting.

Overall, Wildfire is fun and made me remember why I like stealth games. There's a wide range of fun mechanics and the magic is fun to use. There are complaints about the controls and platforming. While not perfect Wildfire is a puzzle game, not an action platformer. DO NOT try jumping over enemies to escape. Wildfire is a good game but not a great game. I recommend it for methodical players who want to take their time to solve a puzzle.

[url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/26701155-The-Pepp-Selection] Click to see my curator for more reviews![/url]

author: {'steamid': '76561198042150137', 'num_games_owned': 608, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 737, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 737, 'last_played': 1638725053}
review:
[u] Gameplay [/u]
Very enjoyable core gameplay, including the stealth and mechanics of each element.  The variety of the missions/levels was great, with the game divided into multiple major areas each with many individual levels.  The structure of each level was a plus, especially the optional objectives you could come back and complete later (I especially enjoyed the time-related challenges).
Each major area was different enough to keep the gameplay fresh, with new objectives/enemies/mechanics introduced in most of them.
I really enjoyed the mechanics of each element the player gained access to, with each having their own specific utility.  None felt especially more useful/fun as any of the others, which encouraged using them all.

[u] Story [/u]
With the protagonist silent, most of the story comes from dialogue or events witnessed from other characters.  The story and setting itself was interesting, especially with how it related to the elements the player gains access to.

[u] Art & Sound Design [/u]
The background and level art was great, very well made.  They were also hugely varied, from jungle areas to snow-capped mountains and eventually to a large city.  The sound design was good as well.  It never got old to hear the panicked screams of enemies once you decide to light the map on fire!

[u] Overall [/u]
Overall a solid game experience, which took me around 12 hours considering I went back and completed many of the optional mission objectives.  I'd definitely recommend this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198103641611', 'num_games_owned': 656, 'num_reviews': 77, 'playtime_forever': 396, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 187, 'last_played': 1673246027}
review:
[b]Wildfire is great fun... if you don't play it the way all the negative reviews tell you to.[/b]

Take a scroll through them, then come back to this review. Notice how they're all complaining about needing to replay levels over and over again to perfect them?

Well, fun fact, you [i]actually don't need to do that.[/i] There are optional objectives, which sort of serve the same purpose as what you'd find in the HITMAN: World of Assassination trilogy. Just like in the recent Hitman titles, those objectives are there to offer replay value and to let you know just how much possibility space there is within the game's mechanics, but they are [i]entirely[/i] optional on a first runthrough of the story.

You get small rewards for completing those objectives, yes, (increased health, longer throwing range, Steam Achievements, etc.) but they're mostly useful for messing about when otherwise fully upgraded. They're not necessary to get any of the cool stealth and combat abilities that actually help you progress through the game... sort of like unlocking new guns and throwable items in Hitman.

If you save the speedrun, ghost, no kill, and no save challenges until after you've gotten a lot of abilities, they're [i]much[/i] easier, way more fun, and more mechanically interesting due to your massively increased selection of skills. Don't just grind out the same level over and over again before moving on. Play it through, maybe complete a few levels without being spotted, but [b]don't be afraid to play through your mistakes instead of restarting the level.[/b]

The unique optional objectives (the ones that each give an achievement) are also often easier with more powers, but they can almost always be completed on a first playthrough of a level if you're careful, so don't be afraid to try for those, just don't restart just because you failed an optional objective unless that sounds fun to you.

TL;DR: If you don't enjoy repeatedly failing optional objectives, just move on to the next level. You'll get better, your abilities will get better, you will have a lot more fun if/when you come back to complete them, and you'll progress through the upgrade tree a lot faster too. Try not to reset unless you need to, because finding solutions to messy situations is [i]super[/i] fun!

author: {'steamid': '76561198043268673', 'num_games_owned': 599, 'num_reviews': 283, 'playtime_forever': 71, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 62, 'last_played': 1646007122}
review:
This is a puzzle game that has a speedrun among objectives. I don't think puzzles and speedrunning mix very well.

Puzzles are the content of this game and I consume them by solving them. Repeating them again makes as much sense as spitting out that amazing wine you just tried back into the glass and then trying it all over again. It works for some optional objectives, where you have to find alternative solutions, but it doesn't work for speedrunning, where there's 1 solution and you just have to practice it to beat a time target.

Imagine doing a puzzle. Let's say a crossword. It takes you 10 minutes to finish. You know all the answers and now you have to do it 10+ times, until you can fill in the words quickly enough. It's not my idea of fun.

review: I really wanted to like this game but the options do not save and the controls are terrible, at least with controller. developer_response: It actually sounds like you're experiencing a bug a few other players have had with the Steam Controller Input settings. Can you right click on the game > go to Properties > and set Steam Input Per Game to "Forced Off", and let me know if that fixes it? Further info in this thread here! https://steamcommunity.com/app/431940/discussions/0/2252308752479897891/#c2297346107935971860 Sorry you experienced this!

author: {'steamid': '76561198196135857', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 599, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 599, 'last_played': 1643906571}
review:
What a gem! I wasn't expecting much but the storyline, pixel art and music are just top notch.
You play as a nobody from a village who stumbled upon a magical meteor shard and is hunted down by an army of witch hunters while trying to rescue your fellow villagers.

Congrats to the team behind it. I really wish there was another chapter or endless mode (you can replay the campaign with some unlockables after beating the game). It's a solid 9-10 hour game and can be way more if you want to unlock all perks and achievements.

review: Game is pretty cool, it's very pretty, and the environmental effects are pretty fun to play with. Nonetheless, the upgrade system is a huge problem for anyone trying to progress through the game and enjoy their time doing so. Unfortunately, the "spirit" upgrade points (which affect the character generally, as opposed to upgrading fire/water/earth) are locked behind Assassin's Creed style "check-list" objectives. Some of these checks are normal, such as beat the level undetected, without kills, or doing the "optional" objective; however, checks such as "no save reloading" and "speedrun" simply aren't feasible without playing the levels a couple more times than is fun doing. Even trying to ignore these points, I just keep coming to a point in this game where I want to turn it off, not wanting to bother. It doesn't help that *some* of the levels in this game have been an absolute drag either.

author: {'steamid': '76561198029254070', 'num_games_owned': 1209, 'num_reviews': 333, 'playtime_forever': 702, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 702, 'last_played': 1641507924}
review:
Skradanka, miks trudnej, nudnej i żmudnej, czyli frustrująco-odrzucającej. Niestety sądziłem, że elementy logiczne będą tu nieco istotniejsze, tak jednak nie jest. Założenia są dobre, nawet bardzo, jednak sama rozgrywka nie dawała od pewnego momentu mi już większej frajdy. 
Wildfire  zamiast sprytnych zagadek do czego wydaje się stworzona ma duże, rozbudowane mapy, które w efekcie są po prostu uciążliwe.
To co jest jednak tutaj najgorsze to właśnie ten grind. Przejdź poziom lepiej to dostaniesz lepsze/więcej umiejętności, albo męcz się na każdym kroku okresowo licząc na czyste szczęście. Stały rozwój naszej postaci sprawia też, że grze brak płynności - bo ciągle coś się zmienia. Są jeszcze umiejętności pasywne, które na jednych mapach sprawdzą się lepiej a na innych wcale. Żeby maksować poziom, trzeba mocno kombinować. Poczucie upływającego czasu nie mijało mi na krok.
Od około 1/3 gry zastanawiałem się czy gra skończy z łapką w górę, czy w dół. Częściej było w dół, ale i na plus się zdarzało. Kocham skille przedstawione w grze, na prawdę chciałbym zagrać w taką grę, ale logiczną, a nie skradankę.

Grę oceniam na 4,5/10, ale ze względu na moją antypasję do skradanek co mocno wpływa na odbiór gry, to że udało mi się ją ukończyć, oraz to, że ostatni boss był dość łatwy i nie zrujnowało wszystkiego do reszty to łapka w górę.

review:
Lovely!

On the first playthrough I felt there aren't enough levels or enough uses for all the mechanics and things in the game. But once I started going through new game plus, I realized everything is perfect like it is.

Having a level editor would be nice because the potential is huge with all the guard types, plants, carpets, chickens, elevators etc. But there's a lot of levels like this and you can always get a bigger challenge. That's the beauty of stealth games, same places can be played differently and give you a totally new experience.

review:
A pretty nice pixelart game based on stealth with lots of ways to proceed depending on your elemental powers and stuff. I had a great time with it. Grata sorpresa con esta pequeña joyita pixel art de sigilo en 2D. Hay bastante variedad de formas de avanzar y proceder, dependiendo de tus preferencias y las habilidades que tengas en el momento. Me ha gustado bastante. Además tiene modo cooperativo, por lo que se le añade diversión si tienes un compi al que le guste planificar también la estrategia a seguir para poder avanzar. Las habilidades con los diferentes elementos es entretenida y también tienes algunos desafíos para conseguir logros. Definitivamente, no mata, pero es un juego de lo más entyretenido y recomendable para los fans del género. Recomendado, y si aún así no lo tienes claro, prueba la demo. A jugar!

author: {'steamid': '76561198179689122', 'num_games_owned': 1073, 'num_reviews': 68, 'playtime_forever': 372, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 372, 'last_played': 1638690981}
review:
You can continuously pump water directly into someone's throat, causing them to asphyxiate to the point of unconsciousness, then throw their limp body into a (pit of spikes/incinerator/large body of water) to have them die a long a painful death. And the game doesn't tell you this in the tutorial, so it's a pretty damn good game.

In addition to all the basic stuff feeling good right off the bat (particularly the weight of the characters), Wildfire excels at player driven comedy. In my playthrough, I found myself playing around with the weaker enemies to try to manipulate their "unaware" states. For example if you pop up right behind someone, they will always jump backwards, startled. Yes, that means off cliffs and into wildfires. Top notch stuff, and the situations that you can create are just great.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048141445', 'num_games_owned': 2663, 'num_reviews': 85, 'playtime_forever': 568, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 568, 'last_played': 1636137896}
review:
[i] “Dlatego alchemia jest niewinną nierządnicą, która ma licznych kochanków, lecz wszystkich zwodzi i żadnemu nie pozwala wziąć się w objęcia. Zamienia głupców w wariatów, bogatych w nędzarzy, filozofów w durniów, a oszukanych w złotoustych oszustów...“ [/i] 
[b] Johannes Trithemius [/b]

Wildfire miałem okazję doświadczać ze swoją kochanką. Jak to zazwyczaj bywa, utworzyliśmy w tym celu coś na wzór dwuosobowego rezonatora, na kształt elektrycznego kondensatora, magazynując i wzmacniając energię doświadczenia. Korzystając z przychylności ducha [i] Humulusa [/i] i [i] Canny [/i] zatopiliśmy się w pixelowym świecie pełnym magii, w którym każdy żywioł spełnia swoją rolę i jest wypełnieniem pocałunku między mikroświatem a makroświatem. Jakże wielkie, jakże tajemnicze są wiosenne noce na brzegu morza, kiedy wiatry są ciche i żywioły spokojne. Podniosła cisza rządzi naturą. Samotna, srebrzysta, ledwo słyszalna fala, gdy przepływa pieszczotliwie nad wilgotnym paskiem, całując muszle i kamyki w swej podróży w górę i w dół, dociera do ucha jak miarowy, spokojny oddech śpiącej piersi. [i] „Jakże małym, jakże nieznaczącym i bezradnym czuje się człowiek podczas tych cichych godzin, kiedy stoi pomiędzy dwiema gigantycznymi wielkościami: usianą gwiazdami kopułą na górze i śpiącą ziemią na dole. Niebo i ziemia zanurzone są we śnie, ale ich dusze czuwają i rozprawiają, szepcząc do siebie wzajemnie niewysłowione tajemnice. To wtedy okultystyczna strona Natury unosi dla nas swój ciemny woal i ujawnia sekrety, których nadaremnie szukamy, by wydrzeć jej podczas dnia.” [/i] Owe zanurzenie pozwala zrozumieć głębię treści ukrytych pod przykrywką pojedynczych pixeli i wynieść z tego światło refleksji.

review:

author: {'steamid': '76561198059361840', 'num_games_owned': 1182, 'num_reviews': 1031, 'playtime_forever': 348, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 348, 'last_played': 1632419985}
review:
Wildfire is a really cute but short (6 hours) indie game.

This game is set in the Middle Ages. Inquisition (witch hunt) is still common. The two main characters you play in co-op are witches. The monarch's soldiers try to kill them, but they do not succeed. Instead, each time they try to kill them, the witches acquire the element they were supposed to be killed with. First fire, then water, then earth.

The game is divided into small levels. You have to reach the end and travel through different regions to do so. You learn new skills, rescue prisoners, kill soldiers and sneak around a lot. This game is very much about staying undetected, mastering jump and runs and using your abilities logically.

The pixel art style is well done. The story is nothing special, but it is quite nice. The soundtrack was very nice and always appropriate to the situation.

Really great game if you play it with a friend. A really welcome surprise! I absolutely recommend this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008376294', 'num_games_owned': 546, 'num_reviews': 501, 'playtime_forever': 61692, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 18016, 'playtime_at_review': 121, 'last_played': 1712419103}
review: On both the surface and deep within, Wildfire is a success, and we definitely see this as a franchise in-waiting. Hopefully all the fanfare and positive critical reception the game has received so far continues, and we see it go beyond even Sneaky Bastards’ own expectations. There’s room for it to land on consoles down the track too, where it would fit nicely. Especially having played it on PC using a controller (which I found more rewarding than the initial mouse and keyboard approach). But all of that will depend on how it’s openly received by punters now that it’s out in the wild.

review:

author: {'steamid': '76561198040355852', 'num_games_owned': 296, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 392, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 392, 'last_played': 1630749821}
review:
2Dステルスアクション

曲とデザインが美しい2Dのステルスアクションゲーム。
火水草の属性を使った妖術で兵士を困惑させる要素がメイン。スピードランや主人公の強化などもあり、やり込もうと思えばやり込める。自分は好きな属性だけいっぱい強化してそれを兵士に投げつけてスタンさせたり草むらと蔦塗れにしたりした。

目についた欠点は
・火と草はたくさんシナジーがあるけど水は日を消せるくらいしかわからなかったので属性感のシナジーが薄い気がする。
・ラスボスが急に普通のアクションゲームでステルス向けの強化をしていたせいで酷いストレスを感じた。
・ヤマネコが面白かったがヤマネコが使えるステージが少ない。
くらいで全体的に高品質。

拾った火とかでいたずらがしたいプレイヤー、高品質のピクセルアートと音楽が気になるプレイヤーにおすすめ

author: {'steamid': '76561198205976033', 'num_games_owned': 228, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 1109, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1109, 'last_played': 1630681468}
review:
本来以为是充库存的小游戏，被延长的假期里闲着没事断断续续几天给通关了，体量虽小，但质量是出乎意料的高。
游戏非常友好，操作简单而不简陋，强烈推荐手柄。像素画风配上欢快洗脑的旋律，和敌人蠢萌的对白一起让我玩了几分钟后就爱不释手。
游戏想通关非常容易，但像我这样的ocd必须每关尽可能全收集全成就才心满意足，有的关卡也是为了一个成就反复读档花了很多时间。
比起基本的解谜游戏，wildfire最大的亮点就是其自由度非常高，可选搭配种类和过关方式多样。整体上协调的画风和配乐、角色塑造也为之增色不少。但美中不足的是敌人的重复性太大而且种类太少，基本就那两样，不过对于一个解密闯关游戏来说这不是硬伤，毕竟较高的自由度已经在闯关时足以掩盖敌人设置的缺点。
平均下来每关不到半个小时就足够，适合短时间放松来一关。全流程走完大概也不过10小时。

review:
- Co-op is impossible, the delay is to big. Be it if they have the game or not. There internet being perfect, it has no effect.

- There are auto saves that take over saves you don't want to be saved over. 

For ex. At one point i was at the exit with all but 1 villager to rescue. But at the bottom there where bobcats. I had fire but the villager did not want to go down unless i did. In doing so i got bounced around by bobcats like no ones business. Every hit passing the checkpoint and regenerating to full HP. Result, the only save i had left was the one right before the bobcat would attack me. And i would need to do the entire mission again. And i just did it perfectly and i was literally right at the exit. That shit is just baaaad.

- You can only have 3 skills active. So if you pick the wrong skill toy need a checkpoint or reset to swap them out. Yhea everyone loves that

- The skills you get are pretty useless except for some levels if you want to do them perfectly. Fire is all you need half the time. With a vine or water bubble now and then just cuz the map needs you to use it.
